content: @Amanieu I was surprised to find that the page at https://doc.rust-lang.org/core/arch/macro.asm.html didn't contain any documentation on usage of asm!. By looking at the stabilization PR I see that the docs were split between the reference and rust-by-example, but I think that's going to be non-obvious to users who will probably think of checking the stdlib docs first as the "canonical" location for API documentation. I know that asm! is more language-feature-adjacent than many stdlib items, but as precedence the stdlib API docs also contain material on format strings (https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fmt/index.html), which, like asm!, are essentially a language-level DSL. At the very least the page for core::arch::asm should link to where the asm! docs are right now (ideally as a beta backport), and I'd suggest that at some point in the future that page should contain docs that are useful for users (as opposed to the reference, which contains docs that are useful for implementors, or rust-by-example, which contain docs that are useful for learners)
There used to be a link to the unstable book which I had to remove during stabilization (due to submodule issues).
@bstrie Feel free to r+ that PR. And perhaps even nominate it for backporting to beta?

hm, it looks like the rust-by-example link still doesn't exist, which is weird since https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-by-example/pull/1483 has merged. but there's nothing at https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/rust-by-example/unsafe/asm.html
it also doesn't show up anywhere in the rust-by-example sidebar or search
Which is why it wasn't in the docs before.

ah, I didn't realize this was a submodule, so we just need to bump it in the rust repo to get it to build on the site? I can submit a PR for that today, and then when that's up I can r+ that PR (or I can try, I'm pretty sure I don't have the authority, but I am listed as a suggested reviewer???)
@bstrie Ah, the submodule bump is already included in my PR.
